awd_titl_txt: A Systematic Review of STEM Learning and Social-Emotional Development in Out of School Time
awd_abstract_narration:
Research suggests that when both science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education and social-emotional development (SED) are supported in afterschool, summer, and other informal settings, young people can better develop skills for the future such as leadership, decision-making, and relationship-building so they could have successful careers/participation in STEM. However, researchers and practitioners working in the out-of-school time (OST) sector often do so without connections across these fields. The appeal for more integration of STEM and SED in OST program delivery and data collection has remained abstract and aspirational. This Literature Review and Synthesis project is the next step needed to move the OST field toward the intentional, explicit, and evidence-based integration of STEM and SED in research and practice. The project will create shared understanding necessary to improve program content, staff training, and evaluation. This synthesis will support future research on unified STEM+SED that can lead to more effective, equitable, and developmentally appropriate programming. Improved programming will contribute to talent development, address STEM workforce needs, and promote socioeconomic mobility to benefit children, youth, educators, and society. This project is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments.

This project will systematically examine what domains and skills at the interface of STEM+SED are most researched among K-12 youth in informal STEM learning environments, compared to formal STEM educational environments. The team will further explore how gender, race, and other intersectional forms of equity can be added to the STEM+SED equation. The project team will search and appraise empirical and gray literature (2001-2020) to identify the most commonly researched domains and skills at the interface of STEM+SED in informal environments serving K-12 youth. The review and synthesis process will include four steps: search, appraisal, synthesis, and analysis. The search will begin with STEM+SED skills in four foundational domains (agency, belonging, engagement, and reflection) identified previously with experts from the fields of STEM and SED. The search will include all existing, eligible references from formal K-12 settings to contrast commonly studied domains and skills (e.g., perseverance, self-regulation, teamwork, complex problem-solving, self-awareness) in formal versus informal learning environments. The study approach will then compare these domains and skills by the demographics variables noted above. Following the creation of a strong catalog of evidence, information will be synthesized using three “pillars” for building coherence in STEM+SED integration: phenomenon (the knowing), implementation (the doing) and assessment (the result). These pillars will be used to organize and critically analyze the literature. Building conceptual coherence through a systematic review and synthesis of literature from the fields of STEM and SED will lead to greater understanding of STEM+SED in OST practice, highlight the most important content and skills to learn in informal environments, and identify when and how youth should learn specific content and skills at the interface of STEM+SED. Applying coherence to the integration of STEM+SED ensures that the principles and practices are layered carefully, in ways that avoid superficial checklists or duplication of effort and build meaningfully upon young people’s knowledge and skills. The long-term goal is to broker connections and alignment of STEM+SED across schools and OST programs. Recommendations and a roadmap to guide equitable, effective STEM+SED research, practice, and policy will result from this research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
Context: This systematic review was conducted to support learning environments that strengthen the integration between science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) and social-emotional development (SED) in out-of-school-time (OST) programs. For this project we found, assessed, and synthesized all literature focused on skills important to the fields of STEM and SED among youth ages 5 to 18 in OST settings (e.g., afterschool clubs, summer programs).

OST/informal settings were examined because many such programs focus on STEM content to increase youth engagement and interest. The term SED includes 21st century, resiliency, and social-emotional learning (SEL) skills. Many SED skills support youth participation in STEM and promote youth success in future STEM careers, such as: perseverance, self-awareness, leadership, decision-making, and teamwork.

Review and Analysis Process: In this review, five academic databases were searched to identify all literature published between January 1, 2000-July 8, 2022 related to K-12 youth in OST STEM learning environments. These searches yielded 31,085 publications, which passed through multiple stages of review to eliminate irrelevant results. Ultimately, we identified and extracted data from 709 publications.

Initially, we expected to find a relatively small number of relevant works. Instead, we found there is an active and growing body of literature examining the intersection between STEM+SED, with a large increase in the number of publications on this topic since 2017 (see Figure 1). We also found that significantly more publications identified DEIA as a key concern than provided some or no DEIA acknowledgement. It will be important to continue to track and assess how this literature develops. 

After extracting data from the relevant 709 publications, we synthesized the data according to the three "pillars" for building coherence in STEM+SED integration: "phenomenon", "implementation" and "assessment". These pillars evolved from the findings of a previous conference on STEM+SED (funded by NSF Award #1940155). Within the phenomenon pillar, SED skills were organized to fit into five domains (Agency, Belonging, Active Engagement, Reflection, and Creativity/Resilience), four of which are components of the differential domain theory known as the Clover Model (Noam & Shah, 2014; Noam & Triggs, 2018).

Findings:

Pillar #1 (Phonomenon): More than three-quarters of the 709 publications provided a theoretical foundation to support their STEM+SED work, with over 300 frameworks/theories cited. Only about one-third of eligible publications explicitly defined one or more SED concepts/constructs of interest. Although we are pleased that there is a diversity of terminology and theoretical support for STEM+SED work, this finding emphasizes the importance of using broad categories to organize terms, as we have done in this review. It also indicates a lack of consistency and consensus around SED terms and theory in the context of OST STEM.

When mapping the number of OST STEM publications by SED domains over time (see Figure 2), we found the majority of publications focused on the Reflection/Understanding domain (n=500, 70.5%); the most common terms included problem-solving, identity, and critical thinking. This demonstrates that SED includes cognitive processes, in addition to the affective and social components inherent in the term "SED"; we found that STEM provides a bridge connecting these skills.

Pillar #2 (Implementation): We also wanted to understand the different ways OST programs combine STEM with SED. We organized the publication data into 13 categories and found the most common implementation categories were "Hands-on experiences", "Group or peer-to-peer activities", and "Youth expression opportunities", followed by "Partnerships with communities, businesses, or educational institutions", "Student's choice activities", and "Role models, presenters, and visitors". The most frequent categories are inter-personal or inter-organizational, not focused on the individual.

Pillar #3 (Assessment) Findings: The majority of publications had a research focus (i.e., quantitative, qualitative, or mixed-methods studies). Our Weight of Evidence (WoE) appraisal of the studies (n=528) revealed that the overall evidence base is weak to adequate, particularly for qualitative and mixed-methods studies. These publications were extracted to better understand the evidence for the connection between STEM+SED practices/skills. The most common forms of data collection were "Student/youth self-report surveys", "Individual Interviews", "Non-Standardized Observations", and "Artifacts". Many studies used multiple measures. The evidence suggests that a range of measures are used to examine the intersection between STEM+SED; there is not yet a consistent or standardized group of measures being used across the field (see www.pearweb.org/atis for a database of available measures). 

Next Steps: With further analysis of the data collected through this project, we will create recommendations regarding practice, research and policy in the fields of STEM and SED in OST settings. Our findings and recommendations can help create a roadmap for equitable, effective STEM+SED integration. We anticipate that this systematic review will provide a strong foundation for researchers and practitioners to intentionally, effectively integrate STEM+SED for K-12 youth across the world.


Last Modified: 10/26/2023
Modified by: Gil Noam

Images (1 of )
  • Examination of the number of eligible publications over two decades (January 2000 to July 2022) revealed a positive trend in the number of publications focused on STEM and SED.

    Gil Noam
    References over time
  • Most publications focused on Reflection/Understanding and Agency/Voice. The second and third most common domains were Belonging/Collaboration and Active Engagement. Creativity/Resilience was the least commonly cited domain.
